citations.narrative:
An African Crested Porcupine dug under its fencing and in a separate incident a Bennet's Wallaby exited through a
damaged part of its fencing resulting in both escaping their respective outdoor enclosures. Neither of the animals have
been recovered by the licensee. Escape from enclosures can result in distress, illness, injury, starvation, dehydration or
death of the animal. Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be constructed appropriately for the animals involved and
be maintained in good repair to contain the animals. The facility corrected both enclosures prior to this inspection and
currently adequately contain the remaining animals.
Correct from January 13, 2026, forward.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
An avian environment enhancement plan to promote the overall psychological well-being of the birds is not in place at the
facility. Exhibitors must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to
promote the psychological well-being of the birds and it must be approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by
developing the environment enhancement plan as well as having it reviewed and approved by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by 30 January 2026.

The pool for the demoiselle cranes, ringtail ducks and black swan does not have the water filtration system actively
running, the pool is one fourth full of mostly clear water, and, as waterfowl often defecate in their water sources, there is a
heavy build-up of dark brown particulate material on the bottom and sides of the pool. The facility states it has not drained
and cleaned the pool for some time. The frequency of cleaning and the condition of the water does not suggest adequate
water quality and this may create a disease hazard to the birds. Particulate animal and food waste, trash, or debris that
enters the pool or other aquatic area must be removed as often as necessary to maintain the required water quality and
minimize health hazards to the birds
Correct by 13 February 2026.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
An African Crested Porcupine dug under its fencing and in a separate incident a Bennet's Wallaby exited through a 
damaged part of its fencing resulting in both escaping their respective outdoor enclosures. Neither of the animals have 
been recovered by the licensee. Escape from enclosures can result in distress, illness, injury, starvation, dehydration or 
death of the animal. Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be constructed appropriately for the animals involved and 
be maintained in good repair to contain the animals. The facility corrected both enclosures prior to this inspection and 
currently adequately contain the remaining animals. 
Correct from January 13, 2026, forward. 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
An avian environment enhancement plan to promote the overall psychological well-being of the birds is not in place at the 
facility. Exhibitors must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to 
promote the psychological well-being of the birds and it must be approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 
developing the environment enhancement plan as well as having it reviewed and approved by the attending veterinarian.  
Correct by 30 January 2026. 
3.157(a)(1) 
   
Water quality. 
The pool for the demoiselle cranes, ringtail ducks and black swan does not have the water filtration system actively 
running, the pool is one fourth full of mostly clear water, and, as waterfowl often defecate in their water sources, there is a 
heavy build-up of dark brown particulate material on the bottom and sides of the pool. The facility states it has not drained 
and cleaned the pool for some time. The frequency of cleaning and the condition of the water does not suggest adequate 
water quality and this may create a disease hazard to the birds. Particulate animal and food waste, trash, or debris that 
enters the pool or other aquatic area must be removed as often as necessary to maintain the required water quality and 
minimize health hazards to the birds 
Correct by 13 February 2026.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
